reasoning: Crucial because it targets the main strategic crux of the paper (whether compute bottlenecks actually cap an SIE) and explicitly maps answers to different governance/alignment emphases. Highly paper-specific: it directly engages the paper’s CES/ρ framing and its “strongest-link” rebuttal to the compute-bottleneck objection. Moderately tractable: you can do route-by-route constrained-compute evaluations and estimate marginal gains, but pinning down an ‘effective ρ’, demonstrating robustness, and especially establishing ‘sufficient to reach superintelligence without near-frontier scaling’ is hard and may require long horizons and contested capability metrics. Clarity is decent but has notable ambiguities in definitions (what counts as a distinct route, how to operationalize effective ρ in R&D, what benchmarks constitute ‘major capability gains’/‘superintelligence’, and what ‘without near-frontier scaling’ precisely means). Decision hook is excellent and explicit. Low dead weight: most of the text supports the question and its action-relevance, with only minor extra framing.
title: Existence of compute-light pathways to superintelligence
